item.title: Russia Probes Rail Incidents in Regions Near Ukraine Border
item.description: Russia’s main investigating authority has initiated criminal probes after two bridges blew up in regions bordering Ukraine, crushing passing trains that caused at least seven fatalities and widespread injury.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sills

media:content.media:description: A Russian medic stands next to ambulances parked at Kievsky railway station in Moscow on June 1, 2025, as they wait for the arrival of injured passengers following a bridge collapse in the Bryansk region. TATYANA MAKEYEVA/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: TATYANA MAKEYEVA/AFP

item.title: Emirates Will Keep A380 Flying Until End of Next Decade
item.description: Emirates plans to keep its giant fleet of Airbus SE A380 double-deckers in operation until the end of next decade, as the world’s largest international airline seeks to extend the lifespan of an aircraft that helped lay the foundation for its dominance on global routes.
item.dc:creator: Leen Al-Rashdan

media:content.media:description: An Airbus SE A380-800 aircraft, operated by Emirates Airline, takes off at Sydney Airport in Sydney, Australia, on Tuesday, Aug. 27, 2024. Australia’s government will order the Productivity Commission to assess more changes to domestic flight-slot rules at Sydney Airport to increase competition.

item.title: Airline Industry Benefiting From Lower Oil Price, IATA Head Says
item.description: The global aviation industry is benefiting from lower oil prices because they’re bringing down the cost of kerosene, the head of the IATA industry association said.
item.dc:creator: Guy Johnson, Benedikt Kammel

media:content.media:description: A passenger aircraft, operated by EasyJet Plc, taking off at London Luton Airport in Luton, U.K., on Monday, July 25, 2022. EasyJet are due to report their latest earnings on Tuesday.

item.title: Quant Traders That Dominate US Options Market Move in on Europe
item.description: The option market makers that dominate US trading are taking a bigger share of volume in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Christian Dass

item.title: At Least 22 People Killed After Attack Near Aid Stations in Gaza
item.description: At least 22 people were killed in near two aid-distribution stations in the Gaza Strip, the latest setback to a new humanitarian relief operation backed by Israel and the US as a way of sidelining Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Fares Alghoul, Fadwa Hodali

media:content.media:description: Injured Palestinians are being brought to the Nasser Hospital for their treatment process after Israeli soldiers opened fire at Palestinians trying to reach the points where US aid is distributed west of Rafah city in the southern Gaza Strip, in Khan Yunis, Gaza on June 1.

item.title: Bangladesh Charges Ex-PM Hasina With Crimes Against Humanity
item.description: Bangladeshi prosecutors officially charged former prime minister Sheikh Hasina and two senior officials with crimes against humanity for their alleged roles in violent crackdowns during the 2024 student-led uprising.
item.dc:creator: Arun Devnath

media:content.media:description: Sheikh Hasina, Bangladesh's prime minister, speaks during the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) in New York, US, on Friday, Sept. 22, 2023. Global leaders descend upon midtown Manhattan this week for speeches, meetings and receptions, an annual migration to the United Nations meant to tackle the world's biggest problems.

item.title: Europe Stocks Stage World-Beating Rally as Trade War Backfires
item.description: Europe’s equities have emerged clear winners worldwide as the region’s economic outlook brightens at a time when President Donald Trump’s trade war hobbles US financial markets.
item.dc:creator: Sagarika Jaisinghani, Julien Ponthus

media:content.media:description: Stock prices on the trading floor of the Euronext NV stock exchange in Paris, France, on Tuesday, April 15, 2025. Stocks rose as US President Donald Trump floated a potential pause in auto tariffs, providing further relief to the market after he suspended levies on some consumer electronics.

item.title: Iran Says It’s Not After Nuclear Bombs as It Rejects IAEA Report
item.description: Iran criticized a new report by the UN nuclear watchdog accusing it of nuclear violations, claiming the agency is motivated by politics and reiterating it isn’t seeking atomic weapons.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: A picture taken on November 10, 2019, shows an Iranian flag in Iran's Bushehr nuclear power plant, during an official ceremony to kick-start works on a second reactor at the facility. - Bushehr is Iran's only nuclear power station and is currently running on imported fuel from Russia that is closely monitored by the UN's International Atomic Energy Agency. (Photo by ATTA KENARE / AFP) (Photo by ATTA KENARE/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: Atta Kenare/AFP

item.title: US Job Growth Is Seen Moderating on Shifting Trade Policy
item.description: The pace of US hiring probably slowed in May, with employers focusing on containing costs as households become a bit more guarded and businesses reconsidered investment plans against a backdrop of shifting trade policy.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle, Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Commuters board a Red line Metro train at the Metro Center metro stop in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. A House Republican introduced legislation to block federal funding for the Washington Metrorail system unless it is renamed the "Trump Train," Axios reports.

item.title: Boeing Says New Model to Replace 737 Max Not a Priority: FT
item.description: Launching a new aircraft to replace the best-selling Boeing 737 Max isn’t an immediate priority, the aircraft manufacturer’s Chief Executive Officer Kelly Ortberg told the Financial Times in an interview.
item.dc:creator: Yi Wei Wong

media:content.media:description: Boeing Co. 737 Max Photographer: David Ryder/Bloomberg

item.title: Canadian Wildfires Force Oilsands Evacuations, Stop Oil Flows
item.description: Raging Western Canadian wildfires that have forced thousands of people from their homes are now also prompting evacuations from oilsands projects in northern Alberta.
item.dc:creator: Geoffrey Morgan

media:content.media:description: Wildfire smoke above Highway 97 near Trutch, British Columbia on May 30. Photographer: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin/Bloomberg

item.title: Vietnam Proposes $2b Northeastern Casino Resort: VnExpress
item.description: Vietnam’s Ministry of Finance is proposing an investment policy for a 51.5 trillion dong ($1.98 billion) luxury casino complex in the northeastern province of Quang Ninh, home to Unesco World Heritage Site Ha Long Bay, VnExpress International news website reported.
item.dc:creator: John Boudreau

item.title: White House Prepares to Ease Rules for Big Banks, Politico Says
item.description: The Trump administration is preparing to ease rules imposed on the largest US banks following the 2008 financial crisis, Politico said, citing people with knowledge of the discussions.
item.dc:creator: Alan Goldstein

media:content.media:description: A pedestrians crosses a street in front of Deutsche Bank Center in New York, US, on Tuesday, Jan. 28, 2025. Ever since the global financial crisis, in an attempt to align pay to shareholder returns, banks have relied more heavily on restricted stock units when they’re handing out bonuses. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Untested Banks Find Demand for Risky AT1 Bonds
item.description: Investors are so eager to buy the riskiest bank debt that they’re snatching up securities even from unproven borrowers.
item.dc:creator: Tasos Vossos

media:content.media:description: A Metro Bank Holdings Plc bank branch in Chelmsford, UK, on Monday, July 22, 2024. Metro are due report their first half-year earnings on July 31.

item.title: Meyer Burger to Delay Results as Two Units File for Insolvency
item.description: Struggling solar-module manufacturer Meyer Burger Technology AG requested an extension of the deadline to present its 2024 financial results after its German units filed for insolvency proceedings.
item.dc:creator: Angela Cullen

media:content.media:description: A worker performs quality control on the production line for solar modules at the Meyer Burger Technology AG plant in Freiberg, Germany, on Jan. 18, 2022.

item.title: At 10 AM, Stock Options Soar as Retail Traders Unleash New Bots
item.description: When people talk about algorithmic traders, it evokes images of rooms full of math PhDs creating complex models that place huge trades in milliseconds after economic or earnings data is released. But now, it’s retail traders who are turning in droves to automated trading, building the kind of programs in their basements more associated with Wall Street banks than the Reddit thread r/wallstreetbets.
item.dc:creator: Bernard Goyder

media:content.media:description: S&P 500 Options Volume per Minute in 2025

item.title: Thousands Rally in Bulgaria to Protest Plan for Euro Adoption
item.description: Thousands of people gathered in dozens of cities across Bulgaria to protest against the adoption of the euro as authorities prepare to switch to the European Union’s single currency early next year.
item.dc:creator: Slav Okov

media:content.media:description: A demonstration against Bulgaria entering the Eurozone in Sofia on May 31.

item.title: High Risk and High Reward of Undersea Cables
item.description: Undersea cables carry 99% of the world's internet traffic, but how do these cables work, and are they worth the investment? Google’s first employee of its subsea unit, Jayne Stowell weighs in on how the company paved the way for hyperscalers to take over an industry once controlled by telecom giants. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Adani Energy Approves Raising $502 Million Via Share Sale
item.description: Billionaire Gautam Adani-controlled Adani Energy Solutions Ltd. approved raising 43 billion rupees ($502 million) via a stake sale.
item.dc:creator: Saikat Das

media:content.media:description: Gautam Adani, chairman of Adani Group, at the Kumbh Mela festival in Prayagraj, Uttar Pradesh, India, on Jan. 21, 2025.

item.title: OPEC+ Agrees on Third Oil Supply Surge Despite Russia’s Qualms
item.description: OPEC+ agreed to surge oil output for the third month in a row despite reservations from key member Russia, doubling down on a historic policy shift that has sent crude prices sinking.
item.dc:creator: Fiona MacDonald, Salma El Wardany, Nayla Razzouk, Grant Smith

item.title: How Long Will It Take to Fix Air Traffic Control?
item.description: How long will it take to address the outages plaguing our air traffic control system? Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University Air Traffic Management Program Coordinator Michael McCormick says it won't happen overnight, even as the Trump administration calls for an overhaul of the system. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Investing High in the Sky and Deep in the Ocean
item.description: This Wall Street Week explores problems with US air traffic control and looks at how undersea cables transmit the world's internet traffic.
item.dc:creator: David Westin

media:content.media:description: Sean Duffy, US secretary of transportation, during a House Appropriations Subcommittee on Transportation, and Housing and Urban Development, and Related Agencies hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, May 14, 2025. Duffy released a broad proposal to overhaul air traffic control last week, including the construction of new air traffic control centers while replacing old radars and other aging equipment.

item.title: Where the Stock Market Stands Now After a Wild Start to the Year
item.description: The stock market’s crazy first five months of 2025 have left Wall Street pros in a bit of a pickle.
item.dc:creator: Jess Menton

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Thursday, May 15, 2025. US stocks were on pace to snap a three-day winning streak Thursday, driven by declines in technology, energy and retailers as traders assessed a slew of mixed economic figures.

item.title: Adani Group Outlines Transport Network in Rebuild of Mumbai Slum
item.description: Adani Group plans to build a transportation network as part of the Dharavi redevelopment project in Mumbai that will house rail, road and airport transit facilities in a single location.
item.dc:creator: Advait Palepu, Saikat Das

media:content.media:description: Pranav Adani, director of Adani Enterprises Ltd., right, during a site visit to the Dharavi slum cluster in Mumbai, India, on Thursday, May 23, 2024. With a total market capitalization of $213 billion across 10 listed units alone, Adani Group controls vast swathes of the infrastructure that powers the nation’s growth and underpins the Asian expansion of companies from Apple Inc. to Amazon.com Inc.

item.title: Thailand’s $115 Billion Budget Clears First Parliamentary Hurdle
item.description: Thailand’s lower house of parliament backed a 3.78 trillion baht ($115 billion) annual budget as Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra’s multi-party coalition buried differences to support the spending plan.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana

media:content.media:description: This aerial photo shows vehicles driving along a highway between Khlong Toei slum (L) and high-rise buildings (R) in Bangkok on May 20, 2025.

item.title: OPEC+ Supply Hike of 411,000 Barrels a Day is Main Scenario
item.description: An OPEC+ supply increase of 411,000 barrels a day in July is the main scenario for talks on Saturday, delegates said.
item.dc:creator: Grant Smith, Salma El Wardany

media:content.media:description: An oil drilling rig stands on one of the Causeway islands in the Manifa offshore oilfield, operated by Saudi Aramco, in Manifa, Saudi Arabia, on Wednesday, Oct. 3, 2018. Saudi Aramco aims to become a global refiner and chemical maker, seeking to profit from parts of the oil industry where demand is growing the fastest while also underpinning the kingdom’s economic diversification.

item.title: Charting the Global Economy: US GDP Falls on Larger Trade Hit
item.description: The US economy contracted slightly to start the year, largely reflecting a bigger tariff-related trade hit but also a larger downshift in household spending growth than first estimated.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle, Molly Smith

media:content.media:description: Cranes at the Port of Seattle behind a pier at the Waterfront in Seattle, Washington, US, on Wednesday, May 28, 2025. The Bureau of Economic Analysis is scheduled to release gross domestic product (GDP) figures on May 29.

item.title: Aldi Owners Holding Talks About Possible Merger, WiWo Reports
item.description: The families behind parts of Germany’s Aldi empire of discount supermarkets have held talks about a possible merger, WirtschaftsWoche reported on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

media:content.media:description: ALDI Süd in Cologne.

item.title: India Confirms It Lost Fighter Jets in Recent Pakistan Conflict
item.description: Anil Chauhan, chief of defense staff of the Indian Armed Forces, spoke to Bloomberg's Haslinda Amin on Saturday while attending the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore. He called Pakistan’s claims that it shot down six Indian warplanes "absolutely incorrect,” though declined to say how many jets India lost. It's the first time the Indian military confirmed that it lost an unspecified number of fighter jets in clashes with Pakistan in May. (Source: Bloomberg)
